title: How to Choose the Right RAM for Your PC
summary: A quick guide to capacity, speed, and compatibility when upgrading memory.
content:
Start with your motherboard and CPU support: check whether you need DDR4 or DDR5. Then pick the right capacity for your use-case.

Capacity

  • 8 GB – Light use, browsing, office.
  • 16 GB – Gaming and most daily use.
  • 32 GB or more – Heavy multitasking, content creation, or future-proofing.

Speed and timings

Faster RAM (e.g. 3200 MHz vs 2666 MHz) can help in games and some apps, but only if your CPU and board support it. Enable XMP/EXPO in the BIOS after installing.

Compatibility

Match the form factor (DIMM for desktop, SODIMM for laptop) and generation (DDR4 vs DDR5). Check your board’s QVL if you want to be sure.

When in doubt, use the manufacturer’s configurator or ask at PC Gilmore—we’ll help you pick the right kit.

title: SSD vs HDD — Which Storage Should You Buy?
summary: Understand the difference in speed, price, and best use-cases.
content:
SSDs are much faster for boot and apps; HDDs are cheaper for large storage. Many builds use both.

SSD (Solid State Drive)

  • Very fast load times and snappy system.
  • No moving parts, so more durable and quiet.
  • Best for: Windows, programs, games you play often.
  • Cost: more per GB than HDD.

HDD (Hard Disk Drive)

  • Cheaper per GB, good for bulk storage.
  • Slower; fine for backups, media, and archives.
  • Best for: large files you don’t need to open every day.

Recommendation

Use an SSD for your main drive (at least 256 GB, ideally 500 GB or more) and add an HDD if you need lots of space for photos, videos, or backups. We can help you choose the right combo at PC Gilmore.
